issue.title: transformers refactor: summarizer and base class

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This refactors the `SummaryTransformer` to use the new transformer template.
Some minor changes there - `transform` was still present and overwrote `_transform`, and the "inner type" tags were set incorrectly.

In addition, this fixes two bugs:
* in the base template, appears when a `Panel` is passed to a `Series`-wise transform that outputs `Primitives` - in this case, thet different rows were not concatenated properly (some index issues).
* the base class now enforces that `fit` is called before `transform`, even if the `fit-in-transform` flag as True (which means `fit` is empty and can be skipped, but `fit` still needs to be called). As a shorthand for "transform right away", `fit_transform` should be called, not `transform`.

body:
I don't remember implementing anything to do with the transformer refactor or suggesting any changes to how to deal with multivariate Panel data for Series transformers during the process. If you could point me to where I am involved in this process other than the recent comment, that would be great.

The only thing I can think of is the original SummaryTransformer PR (#1329), where I proposed that additional dimensions be added on as columns? I still agree with this (for my usage at least, maybe there is a better general format).

Currently, when I try to use the SummaryTransformer as the transformer in a pipeline (part of #1063), the multivariate panel data with 40 rows and 6 dimensions is transformed into 240 rows. I struggle to think of a case where I would want this using panel data. Would be best to either add a 3rd dimension to the output, or just add them on as additional columns.

From main:
```
from sktime.datasets import load_basic_motions
from sktime.transformations.series.summarize import SummaryTransformer

if __name__ == "__main__":
    X_train, y_train = load_basic_motions(split="train", return_X_y=True)
    print(X_train.shape)
>>> (40, 6)
    st = SummaryTransformer()
    print(st.fit_transform(X_train).shape)
>>> (240, 9)
```

I don't believe I am doing anything strange here. The input is a pandas DataFrame, but the output is the same with a numpy 3d array also. SummaryTransformer only takes Series datatypes I believe, so this is all happening in the base class automated transformations?

> I don't remember implementing anything to do with the transformer refactor or suggesting any changes to how to deal with multivariate Panel data for Series transformers during the process. If you could point me to where I am involved in this process other than the recent comment, that would be great.

Sorry, I got confused. @RNKuhns implemented the summary transformer, but you were last to review, and I remembered the discussion with you on that, which in memory got distorted into you implementing it.

Regarding the discussion: I think we are not consistent in what we think 2D numpy data means.
By default, it is interpreted as a multivariate series, i.e., 1 instance, 40 time points, 6 variables.
You seem to refer to it as panel data, i.e., 6 instances, 40 time points, 1 variable.

Obviously, both cannot be correct at the same time.
The automated type recognition thinks it is a multivariate series, and I think in general that makes most sense to assume if you are seeing a 2D numpy array and no further information.

What happens in the transform is that the rows corresponds to a product of the variable index and the time index.

All good.

I'm a bit confused. Are we are talking about the output type here? I'm assuming the process is a bit like this: The base class splits up the input Panel data, feeds it into the Series transformer one series at the time, which then outputs a 2d numpy array (or 1d if univariate) for each series. If that's the case, it is all fine and is the expected output.

When it comes to putting those 2d arrays back together for the primitive output, we could probably format it a bit better.

If we are talking input from the above example, the shape is 40 instances, 6 dimensions, 100 time points. The DataFrame format does not give the amount of time points using .shape annoyingly. The output shape is instances*dimensions, with 9 columns for the default summary stats.

>I'm a bit confused. Are we are talking about the output type here?

Well, format primarily - but yes, the output (of `transform`). The output probably has to be `pd.DataFrame`, which is fundamentally a 2D container.

>I'm assuming the process is a bit like this

Yes - each univariate series produces a 1D array/container of length 9. This is stored in a one-row `pd.DataFrame` by convention.

If there are multiple series, you have as many of these as there were series. So, in the example, when you have 40 instances of univariate series, you (should) get a 2D arrays of shape (40, 9).

The question is what should happen if you have multiple variables (in the example 6). Then you can compute the summaries per variable and per instance.

I can think of two natural ways:
* multi-index over columns, this gives a (40, 54) in the example, with a column multi-index of two levels (feature and variable)
* multi-index over rows, this gives a (240, 9) in the example, with a row multi-index of two levels (instance and variable)

Note that since (or as long as) the output container is `pd.DataFrame`, the resulting structure must be 2D - but we can have multi-indices.

If the output type is primitives, I think it is more natural for it to multi-index over columns.

When the output from the transformer is a series, however, neither are great really. If I had to choose, probably multi-index over rows, as things could get strange if the series are unequal length and you start just appending them onto each other.

Do we want to avoid nested DataFrames for the above case? 

Would be good to hear what others think.

> Do we want to avoid nested DataFrames for the above case?

... in all cases, really ...

issue.title: [BUG] Catch22 on multivariate time series extracts 22 features in total instead of 22 features per variable/column

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
<!--
A clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->
I tried to use Catch22 to extract features of multivariate time series.
I followed the example from main/examples/catch22.ipynb
Using the multivariate data from this example I have an input of 40 instannces each with 6 series of 100 data points. (40x6x100)
I would expect 22 features per univariate series so an output of 40 instances each with 6 sets of 22 features (40x6x22), but I have an output of size 40x22.
It's writed: "The default procedure will concatenate each column prior to transformation" in the notebook, does that mean that for each instances, the algorithm take the 6 series (for 6 dimensions/columns) and flatten them in a single 600 data point time series ?
Does the features extracted means something then ? From what I uderstand from catch22 paper, they test their feature extraction method on univariate time series, so I would expect the multivariate version of the implementation of catch22 to apply the feature extractions mehod to each of the 6 univariate time series individually and concatenate the result after. 
**To Reproduce**
<!--
Add a Minimal, Complete, and Verifiable example (for more details, see e.g. https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve

If the code is too long, feel free to put it in a public gist and link it in the issue: https://gist.github.com
-->

```python
from sktime.datasets import load_basic_motions
from sktime.transformations.panel.catch22 import Catch22
BM_X_train, BM_y_train = load_basic_motions(split="train", return_X_y=True)
print(BM_X_train.shape, BM_X_train.iloc[0,0].shape)
c22_mv = Catch22()
c22_output = c22_mv.fit_transform(BM_X_train)
print(c22_output.shape, c22_output.iloc[0,0])
```

**Expected behavior**
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.
-->
I would expect the multivariate version of the implementation of catch22 to apply the feature extractions mehod to each of the 6 univariate time series individually and concatenate the result after.
Like if I use a column transformer on each columns individually:
```python
from sktime.transformations.panel.compose import ColumnTransformer
transformer = ColumnTransformer(
    transformers = [(str(i), Catch22(), [BM_X_train.columns[i]]) for i in range(BM_X_train.shape[1])]
)
c22_output = transformer.fit_transform(BM_X_train)
print(c22_output.shape, c22_output.iloc[0,0])
```
Althought different format of the outputs could work as discussed here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1719

**Additional context**
<!--
Add any other context about the problem here.
-->

**Versions**
'0.9.0'
<details>
System:
    python: 3.8.12
Python dependencies:
          pip: 21.2.2
   setuptools: 58.0.4
      sklearn: 1.0.1
       sktime: 0.9.0
  statsmodels: 0.12.1
        numpy: 1.19.3
        scipy: 1.7.3
       Cython: None
       pandas: 1.3.5
   matplotlib: 3.5.1
       joblib: 1.1.0
        numba: 0.54.1
     pmdarima: None
      tsfresh: None

<!--
Please run the following code snippet and paste the output here:
 
from sktime import show_versions; show_versions()
-->

</details>

<!-- Thanks for contributing! -->

body: So, @MatthewMiddlehurst, you think it should be *column* multiindex, given the merged PR #1869 of yours?
For cases where the output is not a series, yes.

issue.title: [ENH] multivariate series-to-primitive transformers should have return n_instances = input n_instances

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
We need to ensure that multivariate series-to-primitive transformers have return n_instances = input n_instances, as was decided in https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1719.

In particular, we need to ensure:

* for existing series-to-primitive transformers that the "number of rows" (or mtype specific equivalent) of input and output are equal, see #1719
* that the test suite catches deviations from this, i.e., a test that checks for estimators that are both series-to-primitive and multivariate that the number of instances returned are correct

An exemplar that can be used for extension and refactoring is the `SummaryTransformer` which currently produces output (in the multivariate input case) that is non-compliant with decision #1719.

body:
ok, agreed & decided then!

Turned this into todo items here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2717

issue.title: [ENH] pipeline for time series classification from sktime transformers and sklearn classifiers

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR introduces a pipeline object for time series classification where the last object is an `sklearn` classifier.

Differently from current pipeline constructs involving sklearn classifiers, this (a) inherits from `BaseClassifier` and hence also performs all the input checks and conversions, or can be used in further composition, and (b) also allows for both series-to-primitives and series-to-series transformers to be chained.

Currently, the tests are still failing due to use of `SummaryTransformer` as series-to-primitives, and its issue with output signature in case of a multivariate input object, see also discussion in #1719 and todos in #2717.

Depends on https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2720 due to use of `SummaryTransformer` for testing multivariate time series classifiers pipelines (7 of 9 files touched are due to #2720).
